abstract.p: Letter from Comr Martha E Stark of New York City Department of Finance, replies to Aug 10 article, saying Mayor Michael R Bloomberg will indeed get diplomats to pay their parking tickets

block.p: Re ''Bloomberg Finds Some of City's Woes Resist His Solutions'' (Political Memo, Aug. 10): Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will indeed get diplomats to pay their parking tickets. The agreement in principle he signed on Aug. 9 requires them to pay a substantial portion of the debt incurred since 1997 and all future fines.

Collecting this debt has been the holy grail of diplomatic parking. Towing, the enforcement tool of last resort, is exactly what the city has been trying to avoid because it's a waste of everyone's time and money.

Re ''Bloomberg Finds Some of City's Woes Resist His Solutions'' (Political Memo, Aug. 10): Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will indeed get diplomats to pay their parking tickets. The agreement in principle he signed on Aug. 9 requires them to pay a substantial portion of the debt incurred since 1997 and all future fines.

Collecting this debt has been the holy grail of diplomatic parking. Towing, the enforcement tool of last resort, is exactly what the city has been trying to avoid because it's a waste of everyone's time and money.

The Giuliani administration almost had a deal, but it was never finalized. We hope to conclude a deal on Aug. 21 that will improve traffic safety and allow the city to collect debts from diplomats without impeding the important work they do.
MARTHA E. STARK Commissioner, New York City Department of Finance New York, Aug. 14, 2002
